lesson3.topic: go / went / will go / is going
lesson3.help: This lesson teaches you how to talk about groups. Use “we” when you include yourself (“We are friends”) and “they” when you talk about others (“They are at school”). “Our” shows something belongs to your group (“our house”), and “their” shows something belongs to another group (“their car”). Try talking about your family, friends, or classmates using these words. For example: “We love our dog,” or “They forgot their books.” These words are great for teamwork, storytelling, and everyday conversations.

lesson4.help: This lesson focuses on the verb “to be,” which is used all the time in English. Use “I am” for yourself, “you are” for the person you're talking to, “he/she/it is” for others, and “we/they are” for groups. For example: “I am happy,” “She is tired,” “They are ready.” These forms help you describe feelings, locations, and facts. Try making short sentences about yourself and others. This is one of the most useful tools for speaking clearly and confidently in English.

lesson5.help: Here you’ll learn how to point to things and describe where they are. Use “this” for one thing near you (“This is my pen”) and “that” for one thing far away (“That is your bag”). “These” is for multiple things near you, and “those” is for multiple things far away. Try pointing to objects around you and saying “this” or “that.” It’s a great way to practice describing your environment. These words are super helpful when shopping, giving directions, or showing things to others.

lesson6.help: This lesson helps you talk about yourself and others in everyday situations. Use “me” when talking about yourself as the object (“Give it to me”), and “you” when talking to someone else. “My” shows something belongs to you (“my phone”), and “your” shows something belongs to the person you're talking to (“your keys”). Try using these in real life: “This is my bag. Is that your jacket?” Practice pointing to things and saying whose they are—it’s a great way to build confidence with basic conversation.,

lesson7.help: In this lesson, you’ll learn how to talk about other people and things. Use “he” for a man or boy, “she” for a woman or girl, and “it” for objects or animals (unless the animal has a name, then use “he” or “she”). For example: “He is my brother,” “She is a teacher,” “It is a cat.” Try describing people around you or things in your room. This helps you build sentences and describe the world clearly. Don’t worry if you mix them up—just keep practicing!
